Miss Caroline H. Waterman, of
Baltimore and Jacksonville, Florida,
has been named sponsor of the Annual Home Concert of the Hopkins
Musical Club to be given at the Maryland Casualty Clubhouse, Friday,
March 15. Dr. Joseph S. Ames, president of the University, has been selected as the guest of honor.
A graduate of the Agnes Scott College, Atlanta, Georgia, Miss Waterman is a prominent member of the
social set of this city. She will be accompanied by Carson G. Frailey, president of the organization.

Tuesday, March 12, 1935.

Try Again?
THE poor attendance at the "gymboree" last Thursday evening compels reiteration of a recent editorial.
It was brought out in that editorial
that the announcement to the effect
that no varsity "H" sweaters would
be issued to varsity men produced little if any reaction on the part of the
student body due to its lack of spirit
Many thought this an unfair accusation at the time, contending that it
was not possible for the students to
do anything in regards to this situation. This was, however, disproved
by a certain spirited few, still remaining on the Hopkins campus, who
sponsored the "gymboree." The purpose of the gym carnival, of course,
was to raise enough funds to Make
possible the presentation of the varsity sweaters to those members of
the football and basketball teams who
deserve them. Unforttmate17, their
goal was not fully realized—not because this select group did not exert
enough efforts, but because they
were dealing with a student body that
is spiritless and from whom wholehearted support can never be expected.
The opportunity to refute that former editorial was practically placed
in the hands of the Hopkins student,
yet he failed to respond. As might be
expected of such a spiritless body,
condemnation had little effect. The
discouraging result of these concerted
efforts have moved the author of
these editorials to the conclusion that
to instill spirit into a spiritless group
is analogous to instilling life into a
I. L.
lifeless body.

Words And Wisdom
SLOGANS are wonderful things! You
don't have to pay any particular attention,to facts or reason in making
them—just utter your sentiments in
a nice, easy-to-say, forceful-sounding
phrase or so, and you can broadcast
it all over the country without
rhyme or reason.
What brought this thought home
to us was the presence of a thousand
little stickers placed in conspicuous
places all over the campus, asking us
to reject a certain line of newspapers from our list because they
promote race hatred and support Hitler. Now that last statement would
seem to be confuted by nearly every
issue which the worthy owner of the
papers in question puts out. Of course
this undoubtedly misses the whole
point of the sticker's slogan. It was
just put there to arouse our curiosity
or our bile, and implied something
entirely different from it. apparent
statement. But we think that any such
broad statement deserves an explanation, and we ask the sticker-pasters
to give our readers one.
The first statement, alleging the
promotion of race hatred, starts us
to thinking. (Well, it makes us wrinkle our brows, then.) We don't doubt
that the -said newspapers stir up race
hatred (though we are inclined to
believe that that is merely a steppingstone to worse mire), but we wonder
—what about the hatreds which the
sticker-pasters stir up? Are class

Kouwenhoven Speaks
At Baltimore Schools
Will Present A Series Of Lectures
On Engineering In Various
City Schools
Dr. Wm. B. Kouwenhoven, assistant dean of the Engineering School,
is presenting a series of lectures at
the various Baltimore high schools
dealing with phases of engineering.
Dr. Kouwenhoven delivered his
first lecture at the Baltimore Polytechnic Institute last Monday. The
subject of his lecture was the "Effects of the Electrical Shock."

The first scrimmage of the lacrosse
year was puffed through Saturday
afternoon, all the candidates who had
ever played before seeing action. The
only casualties were blisters for Hammer Himes and a sore leg for Jackson
Kaufman where Rube Pasarew had
blocked him with too much enthusiasm.

The defense showed up better than
the attack. The midfield defense, with
Pasook, Don Naylor, Pete Swindell,
and Elm Powell on hand, is as well
taken care of as any coach could
hope for. On the other hand, Otts
Phillips is about the only close defense man of first string caliber. Pasarew, who has a mania for rolling
blocks, will probably drop back to a
point position.

Miss Caroline H. Waterman, of
Baltimore and Jacksonville, Florida,
has been named sponsor of the Annual Home Concert of the Hopkins
Musical Club to be given at the Maryland Casualty Clubhouse, Friday,
March 15. Dr. Joseph S. Ames, president of the University, has been selected as the guest of honor.

social set of this city. She will be accompanied by Carson G. Frailey, president of the organization.

Tuesday, March 12, 1935.

Try Again?
THE poor attendance at the "gymboree" last Thursday evening compels reiteration of a recent editorial.
It was brought out in that editorial
that the announcement to the effect
that no varsity "H" sweaters would
be issued to varsity men produced little if any reaction on the part of the
student body due to its lack of spirit
Many thought this an unfair accusation at the time, contending that it
was not possible for the students to
do anything in regards to this situation. This was, however, disproved
by a certain spirited few, still remaining on the Hopkins campus, who
sponsored the "gymboree." The purpose of the gym carnival, of course,
was to raise enough funds to Make
possible the presentation of the varsity sweaters to those members of
the football and basketball teams who
deserve them. Unforttmate17, their
goal was not fully realized—not because this select group did not exert
enough efforts, but because they
were dealing with a student body that
is spiritless and from whom wholehearted support can never be expected.
The opportunity to refute that former editorial was practically placed
in the hands of the Hopkins student,
yet he failed to respond. As might be
expected of such a spiritless body,
condemnation had little effect. The
discouraging result of these concerted
efforts have moved the author of
these editorials to the conclusion that
to instill spirit into a spiritless group
is analogous to instilling life into a
I. L.
lifeless body.

Words And Wisdom
SLOGANS are wonderful things! You
don't have to pay any particular attention,to facts or reason in making
them—just utter your sentiments in
a nice, easy-to-say, forceful-sounding
phrase or so, and you can broadcast
it all over the country without
rhyme or reason.
What brought this thought home
to us was the presence of a thousand
little stickers placed in conspicuous
places all over the campus, asking us
to reject a certain line of newspapers from our list because they
promote race hatred and support Hitler. Now that last statement would
seem to be confuted by nearly every
issue which the worthy owner of the
papers in question puts out. Of course
this undoubtedly misses the whole
point of the sticker's slogan. It was
just put there to arouse our curiosity
or our bile, and implied something
entirely different from it. apparent
statement. But we think that any such
broad statement deserves an explanation, and we ask the sticker-pasters
to give our readers one.
The first statement, alleging the
promotion of race hatred, starts us
to thinking. (Well, it makes us wrinkle our brows, then.) We don't doubt
that the -said newspapers stir up race
hatred (though we are inclined to
believe that that is merely a steppingstone to worse mire), but we wonder
—what about the hatreds which the
sticker-pasters stir up? Are class

Dr. Wm. B. Kouwenhoven, assistant dean of the Engineering School,

Dr. Kouwenhoven delivered his
first lecture at the Baltimore Polytechnic Institute last Monday. The
subject of his lecture was the "Effects of the Electrical Shock."

The first scrimmage of the lacrosse
year was puffed through Saturday
afternoon, all the candidates who had
ever played before seeing action. The
only casualties were blisters for Hammer Himes and a sore leg for Jackson
Kaufman where Rube Pasarew had
blocked him with too much enthusiasm.

The defense showed up better than
the attack. The midfield defense, with
Pasook, Don Naylor, Pete Swindell,
and Elm Powell on hand, is as well
taken care of as any coach could
hope for. On the other hand, Otts
Phillips is about the only close defense man of first string caliber. Pasarew, who has a mania for rolling
blocks, will probably drop back to a
point position.
